 "Buoyed by a political resurrection in French-speaking Quebec, the Conservatives won the most seats in the 308-seat House of Commons, despite a campaign in which Liberals tried to stop Harper by linking him to American conservatives in general -- and President Bush in particular."
 Maybe Canadians are finally waking up and getting tired of socialism and a govt that tries to define the morality of individuals. Good for them! Too bad they waited until so much damage was done.

 
 Or maybe it was just a reaction to corruption rather than anything to do with policy.
In the end it wasn't an election but a referendum on the scandal itself.
Looking at the house of commons, conservative in leadership, not legislative ability.

I agree that Canada needed a change, I'm not sure it is all for the best. From reading the link posted earlier, it seems that the Canadians are going to take a stronger stand on trade issues with the U.S., the softwood lumber policies in particular.
 The Canadian lumber imports have a huge effect on my states economy. Until recently,the Canadian dollar has been a big factor in U.S. companies ability to compete with cheaper lumber prices out of Canada.
 Another factor, in my area, Maine, is the price Canadians pay for stumpage. A lot of the Canadians cut wood on what is refered to as Crown Land, which doesn't charge the same fees for cutting rights as private woodlot owners do.
 By some accounts they compare Harper to Bush. I'm not sure the Canadians realize just how bad that will turn out if those comparisons turn out to be true.
It's a minority government that's unlikely to effect much significant change whether social or economic. There's little cause for jubilations one way or the other.
